properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the Eastern American Seaboard will move across Eastern Quebec today. This system will bring between 30 and 50 millimetres of rain over several areas of Eastern Quebec. Rain will end this evening over the Gaspé peninsula and the North Shore and Sunday morning over the Lower North Shore. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T00:41:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T08:42:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0937986212.2020
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Matane, Amqui area, Matapédia area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first accumulating snowfall of the season will begin tonight. Snow is expected to begin north of Lake Superior this afternoon and taper off on Sunday morning. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible, however, uncertainty remains high. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. Snowfall Warnings may be required as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T02:17:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T10:18:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0320025466.2020
Area: Armstrong - Auden - Wabakimi Park, Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid, Gull Bay - Black Sturgeon Lake, Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first accumulating snowfall of the season will begin this afternoon. Snow is expected to begin in Northwestern Ontario near noon today. The snow will taper off by late this evening. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 cm are possible. However, with warmer temperatures and a mix of rain and snow expected near Lake Superior, snowfall amounts could be much less along the lakeshore. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T02:17:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T10:18:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3090527761.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Waterspout Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions continue to be favourable for the development of waterspouts over Eastern Lake Erie until early this afternoon. Conditions have become less favourable over Western Lake Ontario, though a risk of waterspouts remains before noon. ### Wind speeds inside the spray ring of a waterspout are 45 knots or higher. Vulnerable vessels are at risk of damage or capsizing. Waterspouts are generally isolated in nature although they can also occur in families of two or more. Waterspouts sometimes appear as funnel clouds with swirling water visible near the surface. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-10-17T23:54:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T14:24:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2095359388.2020
Area: Eastern Lake Erie

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Another 20 to 40 mm of rain is expected over these areas. The rain will taper off from west to east throughout the day. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected continue along the southern shore of Great Slave Lake near and east of the community of Fort Resolution today. Snow squalls will weaken tonight. Snowfall amounts will range significantly depending on where the snow squall sets up, but local total accumulations by Saturday evening could exceed 25 cm. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T01:59:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T17:08:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0517246906.2020
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow will develop in Qikiqtarjuaq on Sunday as a winter storm system moves towards Baffin Island. Snow will begin on Sunday morning and last until it changes to rain sometime on Sunday evening. Before this change-over, Qikiqtarjuaq will see 10 to 20 cm of snow. Rain will persist through Sunday night and will likely erode much of the snowpack. During the day on Sunday, visibilities may be significantly reduced in heavy snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T11:32:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T19:33:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2984584445.2020
Area: Qikiqtarjuaq

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 120 km/h Time span: this evening until late overnight. Location: Wreckhouse area. Remarks: Winds are gusting near 80 km/h, and will gradually increase to 120 km/h this evening. Winds will ease upon shifting to westerly before Sunday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-18T09:59:14-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High westerly winds gusting up to 100 kilometres per hour are expected over these areas overnight tonight. They will gradually diminish beginning early Sunday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
